p: The first type of empirical networks that we use represent self-reported sexual contacts. Two of these data sets—we label them HIV and Colorado Springs—were gathered by so called contact tracing where individuals testing positive with HIV were required to report their recent contacts. HIV data set is from the first study [ 26], which used an observed contact network between HIV patients to argue that HIV is a sexually transmitted disease. Colorado Springs is a larger and more recent contact-tracing data set based on patients from its namesake city in Colorado, USA [ 27]. Contact tracing does not follow contacts of uninfected individuals, indeed HIV only includes positive cases while Colorado Springs also includes uninfected individuals that had sex with HIV positive others.
